Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Northwestern University 2145 Sheridan Road Evanston IL 60208 United States CH4 exists in great abundance and is used primarily as an energy source. Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) is a promising route for its direct transformation into liquid hydrocarbons and H2. Mo/H-ZSM-5 is the benchmark catalyst, but it deactivates rapidly by carbonaceous species formation. Here, we evaluated Mo/H-ZSM-5 formulations as a function of MoOx loading, SiO2/Al2O3 ratio, and Mo loading method for their impact on one-pass catalyst deactivation and after cycles of isothermal oxidative regeneration. The profiles of the rate of methane transformation to hydrocarbons vs. contact time show similar values for all catalysts with Mo/Al< 0.5. Similarly, the catalytic profiles of C6H6 selectivity vs. conversion overlap for all the formulations tested, indicating a non-selective deactivation pathway intrinsic to these Mo/H-ZSM-5 and giving the same active sites regardless of preparation method. Similar trends are observed after multiple rounds of isothermal oxidative regeneration. We then reanalyzed results from three decades of MDA studies. C6H6 selectivity vs. conversion profiles are very similar across most studies with Mo/H-ZSM-5 and related supports. While the rate at which catalysts might traverse the induction, activation, and deactivation phases may be highly dependent on materials properties, only a few pre-treatment or reaction conditions gave fundamentally different behavior. Finally, we broaden the scope to review and experimentally test other transition metals on ZSM-5, highlighting the anomalously-high C6H6 selectivities at low CH4 conversion for Zn and Mn under catalytic conditions similar to those of the benchmark Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst. This meta-review combined with experimental validation helps identify leads for further investigation with respect to reaction conditions and/or catalyst formulation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Methane Aromatization Mo/H-ZSM-5 Catalyst regeneration Non-selective deactivation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Because of the development of sophisticated extraction technologies, natural gas is an abundant resource [1], which has prompted a search to upgrade it to higher-valued chemicals. Natural gas has CH4 as its main component (average 85 % v/v [2,3]), and several different routes for the direct transformation of methane have been explored in the thermocatalysis community [4,5]. At higher temperatures, the two main paths are the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) to ethylene [6] and the non-oxidative methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) to aromatic hydrocarbons and COx-free H2. One of the first MDA systems was reported by Braging et.al [7]. Years later, a more cited work by Wang et al. [8] evaluated Mo/H-ZSM-5, and since then, extensive research on this system has dominated the open literature. The main features of this outstanding catalytic system are summarized as: (i) Mo is the most active metal [9], (ii) Brønsted acidity of the support helps maintain high MoOx dispersion [10], (iii) MFI zeolite architecture enables shape-selectivity to aromatics [11], (iv) MoCx centers are the active centers during MDA time on stream [12], and (v) Mo/H-ZSM-5 shows three distinct performance stages of induction, activation, and deactivation [13]. Mo/H-ZSM-5 is the benchmark catalyst for MDA applications and reaches 10–12 % CH4 conversion with benzene selectivities of 60–70 % [14]; however, this system shows rapid deactivation by coke formation [15]. Although coke formed during MDA evaluation can be removed by oxidative combustion (regeneration), Mo/H-ZSM-5 cannot fully recover its initial performance as fresh catalyst [16]. These deactivation processes and thermodynamic limits are the main hurdle for its industrial application. To slow down the deactivation process, the synthesis of Mo/H-ZSM-5 has been extensively studied, which points out the effect of balancing Mo and aluminum framework atoms to obtain high aromatics yields [17,18]. Reaction and catalyst performance can be further altered by modifying support properties (e.g., reducing acidity [19], adding mesopores [20], or basifying with NH3 [21]), MoOx loading methods (e.g. supercritical solvothermal [22], or chemical vapor deposition [23]), and pretreatment effects (e.g., with CO [24], H2 [25], or diluted CH4/H2 [26]). Other aspects of the literature have focused on tuning reaction conditions to promote benzene formation by temperature [27], higher pressure [28], co-feeding (CO [29], CO2 [30], or H2O [27]), CH4-H2 switching [31], or reactor type [32,33]. There has also been substantial investigation of alternate methods of coke removal, e.g. by H2 [34]. Many previous studies have focused on obtaining maximum yields for the longest time-on-stream possible; however, the deactivation behavior itself is less examined. The characteristic non-selective deactivation of Mo/H-ZSM-5 was first observed by Kim et al. [35] and showed a congruence of selectivity vs. conversion profiles when varying residence time. Razdan et al. showed overlapping profiles under different Mo loadings (using physical mixing synthesis method) and different residence times, under single-pass conditions and after mild oxidative regeneration [36]. This purpose of this work is to comprehensively evaluate Mo/H-ZSM-5 deactivation under different catalyst synthesis conditions including the Mo loading (Mo/Al=0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6), Si/Al2 ratio of the H-ZSM-5 support (Si/Al2=23, 30, 55), and Mo loading method (incipient wetness impregnation, physical mixing, and atomic-layer deposition). Catalysts are evaluated as synthesized and after oxidative isothermal regeneration. These catalytic results are compared and show that C6H6 selectivity vs. conversion profiles (deactivation profiles) substantially overlap, indicating that the same active sites are formed and then deactivate non-selectively in all materials tested. Additionally, we carry out an extensive cross-comparison of the last three decades of results for MDA with Mo/H-ZSM-5 and related materials in the open literature. Data were re-analyzed to illustrate major trends in terms of deactivation profiles and how they are – or are not – altered by reaction conditions or catalyst treatments. The purpose of this meta-analysis is to comprehensively reassess several decades of literature in a way that specifically interrogates deactivation behavior, which may not have been the focus of the original authors. This review does not attempt to address catalyst characterization or mechanistic analysis, which have been done elsewhere and are enumerated below. Rather, this review seeks to demonstrate that the large library of Mo-based MDA catalysts that have been synthesized are more alike in their deactivation behavior than they are different. This review also is intended to illustrate how plots of selectivity vs. conversion are particularly useful to highlight those cases where there are indeed differences in the prototypical MDA catalyst behaviors of induction, activation, and deactivation. Finally, we also consider the deactivation profiles of other metals loaded on H-ZSM-5 for MDA. This review identifies and experimentally confirms that under-studied metals such as Mn and Zn can reach higher C6H6 selectivities at low CH4 conversion regimes compared to Mo-based catalysts and may warrant further study. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation NH4-ZSM-5 zeolites (CBV 2314, 3024, 5524 with Si/Al2 ratios of 23, 30, 55 respectively) were first activated to the hydrogen form by calcination under static air at 550 ºC for 3 h at a ramp of 3 ºC/min. Incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) was used to deposit MoOx using ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate (AHM (NH4)6Mo7•4 H2O, Sigma Aldrich,99 %) on H-ZSM-5 (Si/Al2=30) targeting 1, 2, 4, and 6 wt% (Mo/Al=0.10, 0.20, 0.40 and 0.60, respectively). Additionally, IWI was used to deposit MnOx using manganese acetate tetrahydrate((CH3COO)2Mn•4 H2O, Sigma Aldrich,99 %) on H-ZSM-5 (Si/Al2=23) targeting 5 wt%. Samples are labeled as “X M-Y-IWI”, where X (0.10, 0.20, 0.30, 0.60) is Metal/Al molar ratio, M (Mo, Mn) represents metal, Y is the Si/Al2 ratio of support and IWI the synthesis method. Similarly, to evaluate Si/Al2 ratio of support, three formulations were prepared targeting Mo/Al molar ratio of 0.20 using same Mo precursor materials denoted as “0.20Mo-X-IWI” where X (23, 30, and 55) represents Si/Al2 ratio of H-ZSM-5 support. After impregnation, samples were calcined at 550 ºC for 3 h under 3 ºC/min temperature ramp. For comparing Mo loading methods, physical mixing (PM) and atomic-layer deposition (ALD) were additionally prepared. For PM samples, 0.15 g MoO3 (Sigma Aldrich, 99.9 %) was added to 4 g H-ZSM-5 (Si/Al2=30), mixing and grounded together for about 0.1 h in a mortar and pestle. After this, the sample was calcined at 550 ºC for 3 h under 3 ºC/min temperature ramp. The sample is labeled as “0.20Mo-30-PM”. To synthesize ALD samples, a GEMSTAR XT TM (Arradiance, NUFAB facility at Northwestern University) was used with 1 g H-ZSM-5 (Si/Al2=30) in a sample holder consisting of two 316 stainless steel wire cloths (McMaster-Carr, 500 ×500 Mesh, opening size of ∼ 30 µm) enclosing the powder sample. This was put on a thin steel plate, followed by assembling steel top and bottom holder parts with six screws to lock the powder holder. The GEMSTAR XT TM instrument was equipped with a power supply (SEREN, R301MK11 RF power supply) for O2 and Ar plasma. Mo(CO)6 was deposited on H-ZSM-5 by plasma enhanced atomic layer deposition, PEALD, which allows ALD to occur at lower temperatures than otherwise possible. The following ALD conditions were used: 50°C precursor bottle temperature, 115°C manifold, 150°C chamber. A pulse sequence of 24 s Mo(CO)6, 50 s O2 plasma, and 30 s purge, for a total of 40 cycles. After Mo deposition, samples were calcined at 550 ºC for 3 h under 3 ºC/min temperature ramp. These samples are denoted as 0.35Mo-30-ALD. To synthesize Zn/H-ZSM-5 catalysts, we exploited the vapor pressure of Zn metal. Thus, 1 g Zn metal (Sigma Aldrich, >99.995 %) was held at 400 ºC (Pvapor= 0.083 mmHg) upstream of the H-ZSM-5 catalyst carrying out MDA. See Figure S1 for the reactor geometry, yielding what we call 0.22ZN-30-CVD. A summary of materials synthesized is shown in Table 1 and labeled as “X M-Y-ZZZ” where X is the metal/Al molar ratio, M the metal, Y is the ratio of Si/Al2 ratio of H-ZSM-5, and ZZZ represents the synthesis method. 2.2 Catalytic evaluation Catalytic experiments were carried out in a quartz packed-bed U-shaped tube (1/4’and 3/8’ ends) microreactor using 0.3 g of catalyst as 0.25 – 0.5 mm particles obtained by sieving. All assessments were performed under nominal atmospheric pressure. Thermal mass flow controllers (MKS) were used to feed gases to the system. Figure S1 shows the reactor schematic and dimensions. He (Airgas, 99.999 %), O2 (Airgas, 21 % O2 in Ar), and CH4/N2 95/5 (Airgas, N2 used as internal standard) were used. To prevent product condensation, lines downstream of the reactor were heated at 120 ºC. First, catalysts were heated to 700 ⁰C at a ramp rate of 6 ⁰C /min under 30 sccm He. Upon reaching the temperature setpoint, the catalyst was fed with 22 sccm CH4/N2 for 16 h. The outlet samples were collected after 10 min and every 21 min thereafter. Oxidative regenerations were performed under isothermal conditions at 700 ⁰C. After 16 h time on stream (TOS) under MDA conditions, the reactor was flushed with He for 1 h, followed by 30 sccm O2/Ar feed for 6 h at 700 ⁰C, and another He flush for 1 h, before CH4 was reintroduced. The intermediate flushes were designed to avoid CH4 and O2 contact. Reactant and product identities and concentrations were analyzed using gas chromatography (Agilent GC 6890). An HP-PLOT Molesieve (30 m x 0.32 mm×25 μm) column attached to a flame ionization detector (FID) was used to analyze light hydrocarbons (C2H6, C2H4 and C3) and higher aromatics (C6H6 and C10H8), which were the most prevalent products. Other alkylated aromatics (e.g., toluene) were not detected in significant quantities. An HP-PLOT-Q (30 m x 0.53 mm×40μm) column attached to a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to quantify CH4, using N2 as an internal standard. Further heavier aromatics speciation was not carried out and was counted as coke. Selectivity and conversion were calculated based on carbon as follows: Conversion C H 4 X C H 4 % = 1 − y C H 4 , TCD out y C H 4 , TCD in * y N 2 in y N 2 out x 100 % Selectivity C i H j S C i H j % = y C i H j , FID out * y N 2 in y N 2 out y C H 4 , TCD in − y C H 4 , TCD out * y N 2 in y N 2 out x 100 % Coke Selectivity % = 100 % − ∑ S C i H j Yield C i H j % = X C H 4 * S C i H j Where y C H 4 , TCD in and y C H 4 , TCD out are the corresponding CH4 concentration obtained from the TCD on the feed (during reactor bypass) and effluent, respectively. Similarly, y N 2 , TCD in and y N 2 , TCD out represents the nitrogen concentration obtained from the TC, and y C i H j , FID out represents C i H j hydrocarbon concentrations calculated from the FID detector downstream of the reactor. 2.3 Conversion-Selectivity’s profiles on MDA Literature Catalytic results were collected from publications reported on Web of Science under the search terms: “methane dehydroaromatization”, “nonoxidative methane conversion”, and “catalytic pyrolysis of methane”. Multimetallic-supported catalysts were excluded. The articles selected for analysis of deactivation profile use internal standards to determine conversion and report selectivities by carbon balance (i.e., including coke). The selected publications were grouped based on the MDA strategies as shown in Table 2. Automated data extraction tool WebPlotDigitizer (WPD, Open-source software) was used to extract data from figures. Extracted data are included in the Supporting Information. 3 Experimental results Fig. 1 indicates the effect of Mo loading on XMo-30-IWI (X = 0.10, 0.20, 0.40, and 0.60) under MDA conditions. In Fig. 1a, as Mo loading increases on Mo/H-ZSM-5 from MoAl = 0.1–0.4, there is an increment on C6H6 yield vs. time on stream. However, as the Mo/Al ratio surpasses 0.5 there is a decline in benzene formation, as previously reported [37]. Fig. 1b shows the cumulative formation of C2 hydrocarbons and C6H6 formation is proportional to Mo loading at Mo/Al molar ratio < 0.5, while at MoAl = 0.6 there is significant 67 % drop in cumulative hydrocarbon formation as compared to the MoAl = 0.4 formulation. Figure S2a shows that the net rate of hydrocarbon formation per mol of Mo has a similar rate when Mo/Al ratio is low (≤0.5). Catalytic results on these set of materials have been replotted (Fig. 1c) in terms of C6H6 selectivity (total carbon basis) vs. CH4 conversion. This set of Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts show overlapping deactivation profiles, which indicates a non-selective deactivation pathway with loss of active sites, instead of the formation of new, less-active sites. Only the initial points time-on-stream for the lowest loaded catalysts show some deviation from the trend. This deviation occurs during the catalyst’s induction and activation periods, where catalyst behavior would be expected to be most sensitive to the prior history of the material. This behavior of overlapping selectivity vs. conversion curves has been reported previously by [36] but using a different synthesis method. To further explore if this observation also holds for all Mo/H-ZSM-5 synthesis variables, other sets of materials were also compared. First, the effect of Si/Al2 ratio on H-ZSM-5 supports at similar Mo/Al ratio is evaluated (Figure S3). The effect of the Mo loading method (e.g. ALD vs IWI vs physical mixing) is also evaluated (Figure S4). Lastly, the effect of oxidative isothermal regeneration is examined for the representative sample 0.20Mo-30-IWI. Six cycles of 16 h MDA evaluation followed by 6 h of oxidative regeneration were carried out (Figure S5). During isothermal regeneration, an irreversible deactivation of the catalyst is observed [34] due to the destruction of the catalyst framework, but here, this was chosen deliberately as a form of ‘accelerated’ lifetime testing to assess whether there were fundamental performance changes with extended use and attendant catalyst restructuring. All of these results are plotted as deactivation profiles in Figs. 2a-2c. In all cases, the deactivation profiles have overlapping curves of C6H6 selectivity vs. CH4 conversion. Overall, these systematic evaluations on Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts all show extremely similar selectivity vs. conversion profiles indicating that i) very similar sites are formed on these materials regardless of catalyst preparation and ii) these materials primarily deactivate by non-selective loss of the sites in Mo/H-ZSM-5 under MDA conditions. All Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts show a maximum selectivity of ∼70 % to benzene across a plateau in CH4 conversion from ∼4 % to ∼10 % conversion. The very outset of the reaction gives the highest conversions. This region on the far right of the plot corresponds to induction and activation periods. In this region, the performance can be rather variable as the catalyst forms the active carbide phase. As time on stream proceeds, the catalysts lose activity while maintaining similar selectivity in the middle region in which active sites are non-selectively lost. Finally, the catalysts approach zero conversion and zero selectivity as remaining MDA active sites are lost on the far left portion of the plot. This trend was first observed by [35], in which residence time was varied using the same Mo/H-ZSM-5 composition. Another study [36] reported similar results by varying Mo loadings on Mo/H-ZSM-5 synthesized using physical mixing method. Our results show that this overlapping of C6H6 selectivity vs. conversion is probably a universal behavior of Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts, indicating similarity in active sites regardless of synthesis method or composition. It must be emphasized however, that catalysts may traverse along this deactivation profile at very different rates, and they may start at different levels of conversion. Alternatively stated, the materials differ in how quickly active sites are formed, how quickly they coke, and how many there may be, but there are large similarities in the intrinsic nature of these sites. To further evaluate the potential universality of this trend, and to better highlight cases where substantial deviations are possible, 30 years of open literature of MDA have been recollected, reanalyzed in this form, and compared. 4 Assessment of current literature on conversion-selectivity profiles The articles selected for re-analysis are summarized in Table 2; this selection does not guarantee complete coverage of all MDA literature. Most of these publications reported their catalytic results as figures that contain conversion (selectivity, rate) vs. time, and extraction of data was accomplished using WebPlotDigitizer. These publications were qualitatively categorized based on various approaches including composite catalyst beds, cofeeding effects, Mo loading, catalyst pretreatment, Mo loading method, reaction conditions (residence time, temperature, switching cofeed, and reactor type), support modification, and finally, transition metals other than Mo. After this, CH4 conversion and C6H6 selectivities (BTX or total aromatics if available) were plotted and compared in terms of whether the deactivation profiles overlap or if there are systematic offsets that might be detrimental or beneficial. Because of limitations in this data extraction method and because each researcher may be using slightly different methods to report and analyze their results, descriptions of “similarity” or “overlap” are primarily used when catalytic results are within ±5 % and ±1 % for selectivity and CH4 conversion, respectively. Furthermore, this meta-analysis solely focuses on catalytic results interpreted as deactivation profiles, and it differs from MDA review papers that summarize progress on structure-activity relationships [5,10,38,39], analyze mechanisms of methane activation or carbon deposition [14,40,41], or carry out statistical analyses of the reaction performance [13]. None of the conclusions reached in this document are intended to rebut the findings from those works, but rather to highlight areas where similarities exist but may not have been obvious. All data extracted from these manuscripts are also given in tabular form in the Supporting Information. 4.1 Single-pass evaluation of Mo-based catalysts The majority of studies examined only report results for the first use of a catalyst. These studies are sub-divided here based on the qualitative categories described above. 4.1.1 Composite beds The first approach to discuss is evaluating composite catalyst beds containing Mo/H-ZSM-5. The effect of binder material (silica and clay) is evaluated in [42,43], respectively, and their catalytic results replotted in Fig. 3. Binders shift the benzene selectivity plateau to values significantly less than the typical maximum of ∼70 %. They appear to limit the maximum achievable conversion by redispersing the Mo onto the binder material, which is known to be less effective in MDA. We have chosen to lead with this finding for two reasons. First, the drop in performance is immediately apparent in a downward shift of the deactivation profile, showing the utility of this data construction. Second, this is a critical issue that would need to be addressed for the process to be scaled up. All technical catalyst formulations will have binding components, and the high mobility of Mo under reaction (especially regeneration) conditions means that redispersion onto the less active phase is a severe problem [15]. In another study, addition of Ce0.9Gd0.1O2 to the catalyst bed was reported to increase Mo/H-ZSM-5 performance due to its properties as H2 combustor [44]. However, the addition gave no impact on the deactivation profile (Figure S8). In [45] the addition of Zr metal to carburized Mo/H-ZSM-5 significantly increased CH4 conversion above the thermodynamic limits (Figure S9) by forming ZrH2. The same research group in [46] evaluated different distributions of Zr on the catalyst bed and observed a consistent increase in CH4 conversion, which has the effect of extending the deactivation profiles to higher conversion and extending the plateau region of high selectivity (Figure S10). The eventual deactivation profile is not changed, but the optimal region can be substantially prolonged. 4.1.2 Cofeeding Another approach seen in the MDA literature is cofeeding to increase catalyst performance. In [29,30,47–49] the addition of from 0 % to 5 % CO increases C6H6 formation at different CO feed compositions, Mo loadings, and pretreatments. Replotting results from [30,47,48] give overlapping deactivation profiles with or without CO cofeeds (Figure S11-13). A related Mo/MCM-49 catalyst [49] gives a similar effect in Figure S14. Reference [29] used higher reaction temperature (800 ºC) and their catalytic results (Figure S15a) show a longer deactivation to zero activity, at the expense of the constant selectivity plateau. This is an effect of the reaction temperature; CO had no significant additional effect. In [30], the authors evaluated the effect of H2 and CO2 co-feeds (Figure S13). The addition of H2-cofeeding only moves the deactivation profiles to the left, continuing the expected Mo/H-ZSM-5 deactivation path. CO2-cofeeding shifted the plateau region to lower C6H6 selectivity. The effect of cofeeding H2O or CO2/O2 mixtures on aromatics formation was studied in [27,50], respectively (Figure S16a, S17). In these cases, the co-feed enhances conversion but at the expense of benzene selectivity. This is seen as an obvious shift to the right in the deactivation profile, which is undesired at any conversion level, since less of the methane goes to the valuable product. 4.1.3 Mo loading amount and method One commonly studied approach to improving Mo-based catalysts for MDA is to balance the amount of MoOx precatalyst to obtain higher aromatics yields. MoOx loading supported in H-ZSM-5 is explored in [26,34,36,37,51–54,56] in a range of Mo/Al molar ratios from 0.1 to 3.1. These works investigate catalyst activation (the initial heating to reaction temperature) under a variety of non-reductive gases (He, Ar, N2 or O2). Data are extracted from these studies and replotted as deactivation profiles in Figures S18, 19a, 20–23, 25a, 26c, and 27. In these figures, all Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts have a common characteristic of overlapping deactivation profiles that show a plateau of ∼70 % C6H6 selectivity at 6–10 % CH4-conversion, a good example of this behavior is shown in Fig. 4a. Within this series, the effect of the pre-heating in reductive atmospheres bears special attention. Pretreatment in a CO atmosphere is evaluated in [24,73,74], and the catalytic results are shown in Figure S53-55. In those three articles, the effect of CO shifts the deactivation profiles to the upper left, reducing CH4-conversion while maintaining a similar C6H6-selectivity plateau. Preheating in H2 is evaluated in [25,57,78] and reanalyzed in Figure S28, 36, and 59, respectively. This preheat method shifted the deactivation profile to the upper right at higher MoOx loading, giving a higher C6H6 selectivity plateau of ∼80 % and higher CH4 conversions. Another set of studies evaluated the effect of metal loading on Mo/H-ZSM-5 at Mo/Al molar ratios from 0.3 to 6.3 under CH4 or CH4/H2 pre-heat atmospheres [18,21,23,26,56,58,59,75–77]. The catalytic results from those papers are presented in Figure S25b, 26a, 29–31, 32a, 33, 56–58, respectively. In that set of articles, pre-carburizing is also seen to shift the curve to the upper-right at higher MoOx loadings, as exemplified in Fig. 4b. This is one key area where the MoOx speciation of the pre-catalyst may play an important role in dictating the reactor performance. As is most evident in a reference like [26,79] as seen in Figure S26b and S60, pre-carburizing shifts the deactivation profile to upper-right at higher MoOx loading but the overall deactivation curve shape remains the same. This makes intuitive sense, as the effect is to mathematically exclude all the methane consumed during the carburization step, which normally robs catalysts of selectivity at high conversion if they were pretreated in non-reducing conditions. Unfortunately, from a balance of plant perspective, CH4 is still lost to form the active phase, rather than the desired product. We also note that the deactivation curves can be used for diagnostic purposes. Another set of studies at different loadings [42,60,61] does not describe the pre-heating conditions in a way we could immediately interpret. In analyzing the catalytic results of [42], deactivation profiles overlapped over a range of loadings (Figure S6a), which likely indicates a non-reductive preheat. Conversely, for the data from [60,61] in Figure S34 and S35, the overall curve shape is maintained, but moves to progressively higher selectivity with Mo loading, likely indicating a carburizing pre-treatment. Another avenue to tailoring Mo/H-ZSM-5 MDA performance is by exploring MoOx loading methods. Common MoOx loading methods are incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) and physical mixing (PM). These two methods are compared in [25,62] and their catalytic results appear to show unique behavior. However, in analyzing their deactivation profiles, they overlap ( Fig. 5a, Figure S36,37), much like we showed above in Fig. 2b. The effect of the size of the MoO3 precursor particle in the PM method is explored in [58]. This work highlights the seemingly higher performance of catalysts prepared with smaller MoO3 particle sizes, but replotting as a deactivation profile shows no effect (Figure S29a, b). Likewise, different Mo precursors (Mo6: [(C4H9)4N]2Mo6O19, Mo7: (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O, Mo8: [(C4H9)4N]4Mo8O26) were examined with an IWI method in [63], and it was reported that the Mo6 precursor showed higher aromatic yields. However, like with the other results in this section, the deactivation profiles (Figure S38) overlap and actually show a low C6H6 selectivity plateau of ∼35 %. Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) is proposed as a MoOx loading method in [23]. A variety of Mo-organometallic precursors (e.g. MoCl5, MoO2Cl2 and Mo(CO)6) are compared to IWI and PM synthesis methods at Mo/Al molar ratios of 0.3 and 1 [23]. CVD with MoO2Cl2 enables higher CH4 conversion but in Figure S31, the deactivation profiles overlap, suggesting that similar active sites are generated in all cases. Finally, a set of solvothermal syntheses under supercritical conditions were compared to IWI [22]. The deactivation profiles (Figure S39) of the solvothermal syntheses are shifted to the right vs. the IWI route. However, all the curves clearly fall within the ‘activation’ part of the curve. The main advantage of the solvothermal route therefore is probably to enable faster activation, and it is assumed that all the materials would deactivate similar with extended times on stream or reaction cycles. 4.1.4 Reactor operating conditions As with other catalytic systems, Mo/H-ZSM-5 performance depends sensitively on reaction conditions. As mentioned in the introduction, the effect of varying residence time (changing feed flow and catalyst-bed mass) on the deactivation profile was evaluated in [35]. We believe this article is the first in open literature to describe Mo/H-ZSM-5 non-selective deactivation process and is included here as Fig. 5b. This pattern of Mo/H-ZSM-5 deactivation forms the basis of a further kinetic analysis (Figure S20) that concludes that carbidic Mo is the rate-controlling active site [36]. A more recent study on the effect of feed flow and catalyst-bed- mass on MDA performance is replotted in Figure S41 [64] and S42 [65] and reaffirmed the overlap of Mo/H-ZSM-5 deactivation profiles at a variety of residence times. Another study used 800 ºC, higher than is typical for MDA and pre-carburized the catalyst [66]. Its deactivation profiles (Figure S43) overlap at low residence times but show accelerated selectivity loss at longer residence times. The effect of reaction temperature on catalyst performance is reported in [27,64,67] and their deactivation profiles plotted in Figure S16b, S41b, S44; respectively. In those figures, the deactivation profile is shifted to the right, with an increase in conversions at the expense of C6H6 selectivity at any given conversion. Similar behavior is observed (Figure S45) on Mo/MCM-22 as a support [68]. Another reaction condition that has been investigated to alter the deactivation of Mo/H-ZSM-5 is by switching the feed between CH4/H2 or CH4/He to slow down carbon deposition [31,69,70]. Extracted data are presented in Figure S46, 47 and 48; respectively. In those figures, the deactivation profiles overlapped regardless of the switching pattern or residence time. Reference [71] evaluated CH4/H2 switching at higher GHSV, and the switching mode again has no effect on deactivation profile at high residence time (Figure S49). All the previous articles focused on fixed-bed reactors, but membrane reactor configurations for MDA have also been evaluated in [33,72] using mixed-oxide and Pd-based membranes, respectively. The Pd-based membrane does shift the C6H6-selectivity plateau (Figure S51) to higher values than that of the plug flow reactor by the same researchers (from 50 % to 65 %), but the overall curve is not improved relative to other achievable MDA results. The mixed oxide membrane has no effect on the deactivation profile (Figure S50). Finally, a fluidized bed reactor (FBR) configuration [32] also had no effect on the deactivation profile as shown in Fig. 6a. It bears emphasizing here that the absence of any change to the deactivation profile does not mean there is no advantage to a given process condition or reactor configuration. Indeed, configurations are highly desired that slow the rate of deactivation, make regeneration more facile, or improve stability over many reaction-regeneration cycles, even if they do not fundamentally change the deactivation mechanism or the types of active sites formed. 4.1.5 Other zeolite architectures Other zeolite support architectures for Mo-based catalysts have been explored to increase aromatic yields in MDA. The MWW zeolite support architecture, specifically MCM-22, can show high C6H6 yields [55,62,63,80–82]. The effect of MoOx loading in Mo/MCM-22 with an inert pretreatment is studied in [55] as deactivation profiles (Figure S24). Their deactivation profiles do not overlap with each other, while maintaining the concave shape of the curves for H-ZSM-5. This suggests a more sensitive interplay between catalyst activation and deactivation, rather than a fundamentally different deactivation mechanism. Similarly, references [80–82] varied the Si/Al2 ratio of MCM-22. Deactivation profiles (Figure S61, S62b, S63) show decreasing C6H6 selectivity plateaus at higher Mo/Al molar ratios in the range of 0.6–0.9, suggesting that Mo is increasingly found on less effective surfaces. The utilization of different Mo precursors (Mo6: [(C4H9)4N]2 Mo6O19, Mo7: (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O) during IWI-synthesis [63] did not change the deactivation profile for MCM-22 supports (Figure S38a). Other MWW supports such as MCM-36 and ITQ-2 showed lower yields than MCM-22 [81], and a lower C6H6 selectivity plateau, as seen in Fig. 6b, but a similar overall curve shape. The three- dimensional MWW zeolite MCM-49 [83,84] has a wide selectivity plateau between 2 % and 13 % CH4 conversion that is insensitive to Mo loading (Figure S64) and outperforms the next system mentioned. Additional details on this potentially useful system would be helpful to better understand if it possesses operating advantages. Further modifications of the MCM-49 material [84], gave negligible changes to the deactivation profiles (Figure S65) and typical behavior of activation, followed by a plateau, presumably with loss of selectivity at (unexplored) further deactivation. Other zeolite supports, including TNU-9 [85], IM-5 [86], silicalite, MOR [11], and FSM-16 [87] have been investigated. The deactivation profiles of TNU-9 and IM-5 (Figure S66 and S67) overlapped and showed a relatively flat C6H6 selectivity plateau of ∼45 % between 6 % and 10 % CH4 conversion. There is intriguing evidence of improved selectivity at lower conversion. It is not clear from the data presented whether this represents continued slow formation of the active carbide, or something fundamentally different. More study may be justified for these materials. Silicalite, MOR, and FSM-16 have similarly shaped deactivation profiles, but they have notably lower selectivity plateaus than does H-ZSM-5 (Figure S68 and S69). It should be noted that the selectivity of H-ZSM-5 is anomalously high in ref [11]. The detrimental effect of SiO2 and Al2O3 supports was noted in Figure S6b. Beyond the use of a new support, the H-ZSM-5 support can be modified with the goal of improving aromatics selectivity. Many researchers have investigated hydrothermal treatments [88–92], in part because this happens inadvertently during oxidative regeneration steps. Changes to the deactivation profiles are generally minimal (Figures S70-S74), but it becomes clear how the hydrothermal treatments shift the behavior along the deactivation profile, eventually leading to severe loss in conversion and selectivity after more extreme treatments, as shown in Fig. 7a. Another extensively investigated approach is to create mesoporosity in the ZSM-5 material. Routes include treatment with NaOH [93,120] and carbon addition during synthesis [20,94]. While there may be changes to the rates of deactivation, there are negligible changes to the overall deactivation profiles (Figures S75-S78). H-ZSM-5 external surfaces have been passivated by silylation [97,98,120], TEOS-CVD [95], ALD [99], and by silicalite deposition [96]. These treatments have been reported to increase catalyst overall performance, usually in terms of aromatics yields. These external support modifications can be best described as expanding the deactivation profiles by increasing the selectivity at any given level of conversion. Depending on how the investigators chose to conduct their experiment, this can be seen as a shift to the upper-right, increasing selectivity especially during the activation period (Figures S79, S80, S82, S83), or a shift to the upper left (Figure S81), increasing selectivity during deactivation. Instead of the external surfaces, the bulk acidity can be modified by doping with alkali or alkali earth metals. [19,100]. These studies show somewhat conflicting effects. In one case, the effect of high levels of dopant is to shift the deactivation profile to the upper left (Figure S84). While not clear only from this plot, the dopants may be acting to delay the onset of full catalyst activation, rather than specifically improving selectivity at a given conversion. In another study (Figure S85), Na-doping clearly delays full catalyst deactivation, shifting to the deactivation profile to the left with no improvements in selectivity. Finally, NH3 pretreatment has been evaluated in [21,101] and it has a positive effect on aromatics yields. The deactivation profiles on NH3-treated Mo/H-ZSM-5 (Figure S32b and S86) shift to the upper right, presumably due to better selectivity during the activation stage of catalysis. The specific combination of a NH3-treated support, high Mo loadings, and a carburizing pretreatment can give high selectivity at near-equilibrium conversion as seen in Fig. 7b. Key to successful implementation of such a catalyst would be to maximize stability with time on stream at that level of performance. The Mo/H-ZSM-5 structure also depends on the conditions in which the catalysts are synthesized. Calcination time after MoOx impregnation is evaluated in [102] and the deactivation profiles (Figure S87) show no changes after more than 6 h calcination time, presumably to allow full distribution of the Mo species throughout the zeolite. Calcination temperature is studied in [18] and re-analysis of representative samples from that article (MoAl = 0.2–0.5) show improved selectivity in the deactivation profiles for higher temperatures (Figure S30). As the catalysts deactivate, deactivation curves converge for multiple weight loadings for any given calcination temperature. Deactivation profiles are insensitive to H-ZSM-5 crystallite size in references [43,103] (Figure S7a and S88). Tuning of Al content or Al pairing has been proposed to improve catalyst performance in [104] and [105], respectively. However, there is relatively little impact on the deactivation profiles (Figures S89 and S90). Other forms of H-ZSM-5 have been explored, including hierarchically structured materials [106,107], hollow structures [108,109], and H-ZMS-5 synthesized from different silica sources. The latter (Figure S91) has a significant impact on catalyst performance in the catalyst activation stage, but no large impact on the selectivity plateau. Zeolite structuring (Figure S92 and S93) can help maintain selectivity as the catalyst deactivates, which appears as a shift to the upper right in the deactivation curves. There may be some improvements on the maximum selectivity for some formulations (Figure S94). 4.1.6 Summary of studies on Mo-based catalysts evaluated after a single use After this extensive meta-analysis of deactivation profiles for Mo-based catalysts for MDA, our main takeaways are summarized in Table 3 and illustrated in Fig. 8. Minimal or negative effects are self-explanatory: minimal changes or losses in selectivity at a given conversion. For positive effects, some improve performance in the activation period, some retard selectivity loss as the catalyst deactivates, and some improve the maximum plateau selectivity. Please consult the main paragraphs above and especially the original references for further details. These findings are all apparent at a glance from the deactivation profiles, showing the utility of this construction. One critical issue, discussed below, is that nearly all these effects are recorded only for the as-synthesized materials. Some of these effects, especially those related to catalyst synthesis or pre-activation, may be erased or altered by multiple cycles of reaction and regeneration. 4.2 Studies with metals other than Mo In the 1980’s, Bragin et al. reported catalysts for aromatization of methane using Group VIII metals deposited on zeolites [4] or for Pt-CrO3/H-ZSM-5 [121]. In 1991, Belgued et al. reported that supported Pt catalysts exposed to methane can produce aliphatic hydrocarbons [122]. Similarly in 1992, Koerts et al. expanded the studies of this methane transformation to other group VIII transition-metal catalysts supported on silica [123]. All these studies were carried out in pulse microreactors. In 1993, Wang et al. reported Mo/H-ZSM-5 as a catalyst under flow reactor conditions for methane conversion to aromatics [8]. The outstanding behavior of this catalyst is attributed to MoOx precatalysts being highly dispersed within H-ZSM-5 pores. As reaction proceeds, these highly dispersed MoOx centers are carburized and stabilized by the pore-environment, which then act as the active sites for CH4 activation. Following this report, Mo-based catalysts have dominated the MDA field [14]. In spite of the above, other metals supported on H-ZSM-5 have been proposed for use in MDA [73,111–119]. As for all other work, we have collected performance curves and replotted them to back out selectivity vs. conversion deactivation curves. We have separated out results by reaction temperature; we show results at 700 ⁰C and 750 ⁰C in the main text, and results at 800 °C are shown in Figure S96 [68,112,119]. At 700 ⁰C ( Fig. 9a), the deactivation profiles for metals such as Ni [111], Co [112], Fe [73], and Re [113] are below that of Mo/H-ZSM-5, reaffirming the relative uniqueness of Mo as an effective catalyst for MDA at that temperature. Zn [114,115] showed a higher selectivity than common Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts, but entirely at low CH4 conversions. We experimentally verified this chemistry by synthesizing 0.22Zn-30-CVD and comparing its activity to our own 0.20Mo-30-IWI samples (Figure S97). Our Zn-based catalysts show higher C6H6 selectivities in the low CH4 conversion regime than does Mo/H-ZSM-5, but our selectivity never reaches the heights previously reported. Furthermore, the volatility of ZnOx at these conditions makes further investigation on this system challenging. The results of MDA catalyst testing at 750 ºC are compared in Fig. 9b. The deactivation profile of Mn-based catalysts [116] showed higher selectivity at low conversion than does Mo [68], but this is not easily observed when MDA catalysts are compared only the basis of yield vs time curves. As above, we experimentally corroborated this observation by synthesizing 0.70Mn-23-IWI and comparing its performance to that of 0.20Mo-30-IWI (Figure S97b). Mo-based catalysts showed higher aromatics yield vs. time on stream, but the Mn catalyst is indeed more selective at low conversions. Fe [117], W [68] and V [118] deactivation profiles practically overlap with Mo. Ni [111] and Co [112] have deactivation curves that fall below that of Mo, but the performance loss is smaller than at 700 ºC. Overall, the outlier behavior of Zn- and Mn-loaded H-ZSM-5 compared to Mo is observed only when catalytic results are contrasted in this selectivity vs. conversion curves (deactivation profiles). It is also generally apparent that the uniqueness of Mo/H-ZSM-5 for catalytic MDA is attenuated as temperature increases and non-catalytic pyrolysis begins to dominate. 4.3 Studies after at least one regeneration cycle Beyond the performance of a catalyst immediately after synthesis, there are far fewer studies of catalysts under multiple cycles of reaction and regeneration, and where the researchers have provided sufficient information to calculate C6H6 selectivity and conversion. Instead, it is common to report only C6H6 yields. Moreover, the studies that do provide complete conversion and selectivity data have been done, as far as we can determine, exclusively with Mo/H-ZSM-5. The evaluation of Mo/H-ZSM-5 regeneration under mildly oxidizing conditions (1 %O2/He at 475 °C) for three cycles showed that deactivation profiles of regenerated catalysts overlapped with those of fresh Mo/H-ZSM-5 [36]. Similar studies under different oxidative regeneration conditions were undertaken at 540 °C in [110] and 450–800 °C in [34]. The deactivation curves from those studies are shown in Figure S95 and S19b; respectively, and both figures show overlapping conversion and C6H6 selectivity. Under similar oxidative regeneration conditions, the effect of Mo precursor (Mo6, Mo7) is evaluated in [63]. Its catalytic results are replotted in Figure S38b, and the deactivation profiles of fresh and regenerated catalysts overlap. Under H2-regeneration conditions, Mo/H-ZSM-5 is evaluated and the temperature optimized to maintain aromatics yield [34]. Those catalytic results are included in Figure S19c, and the deactivation profiles resemble fresh Mo/H-ZSM-5. In all these studies, an effective reaction-regeneration cycle balances coke removal with the need to maintain high dispersion of the Mo component and to prevent hydrothermal damage to the zeolite framework. In general, these reported studies and our own experimental evaluations show that the deactivation profiles of fresh and regenerated catalysts overlap, indicating progressive loss of sites regardless of the mechanism of regeneration. 5 Summary and conclusion Direct transformation of CH4 to aromatics under non-oxidative conditions (MDA) has been studied extensively for the last three decades. The benchmark catalyst for this reaction is Mo/H-ZSM-5, but under steady inlet flows, its performance deactivates with time on stream due to coke formation. In this work, we first evaluated common Mo/H-ZSM-5 synthesis variables such as Mo loading, Si/Al2 ratio, and Mo loading method. We studied these materials as initially synthesized and following a deliberately-harsh isothermal regeneration process. All materials under one-pass and oxidative regeneration catalytic tests showed a similar net rate of hydrocarbon formation at Mo/Al< 0.5. We plotted all results as C6H6 selectivity vs. CH4 conversion, which form characteristic deactivation profiles that overlap for all formulations tested and after regeneration. Such curves had been previously proposed [35] but were not recognized to be an intrinsic property, even within one set of reaction conditions. The overlap of these curves suggests that these Mo/H-ZSM-5 all have similar active sites and that they all deactivate by non-selective loss of active sites, both by coking during one reaction cycle and by progressive loss of sites over many rounds of reaction and regeneration. Overall, our experimental results confirm that a wide set of Mo/H-ZSM-5 synthesized by us all display consistent behavior and that the primary differences among these catalysts are the number of active sites, giving the initial rates, and the speed at which they follow the deactivation profile. Then, catalytic results were then manually extracted from ∼100 studies over the last 30 years of published work in MDA. We make no claim that this is an exhaustive list, but several trends clearly emerge, regardless. Replotting catalytic results in terms of C6H6 selectivity (carbon basis) vs. conversion shows that the deactivation curves observed within one study are repeated across different reaction conditions and laboratories. Intrinsic catalyst properties that have little impact on these curves include Si/Al2 ratio of H-ZSM-5, Al neighbor density, Mo loading method, Mo loading level (under inert gas preheat), H-ZSM-5 external passivation (with SiO2) or mesopores on H-ZSM-5. This further corroborates that Mo/H-ZSM-5 deactivation is via non-selective loss of active sites, and it suggests that the synthesis method of Mo/H-ZSM-5 is weakly connected to its performance. We see little evidence that the synthesis method or support can move catalysts to higher selectivity at any given conversion level, and most synthesis interventions have no effect on the intrinsic deactivation curve. The use of MWW zeolites has some promise, but existing data does not allow us to confidently say if the catalysts are fundamentally higher performing, or if they simply transit faster through the activation regime. In the broader context, technoeconomic assessments have claimed that under typical conditions, the MDA process gives a negative Net Present Value (NPV) with standard thermochemical processing equipment [123]. Given the thermodynamic limitations to this process, the route to enhancing process value is through higher carbon selectivity. While numerous studies have been carried out with this goal in mind, no clear path to success is obvious from the literature. When we included other metals supported on H-ZSM-5 in our analysis, Zn and Mn emerge as possible targets, because they exhibit higher C6H6 selectivity than does Mo, albeit at low conversions and with other possible materials handling challenges. We have independently verified these enhanced selectivities in our conditions and with our synthesis methods. The unusually high selectivity of these two metals is not apparent when results are plotted only as yield vs. time-on-stream, as is convention, which highlights the utility of these plots for comparison of catalysts across the literature. Beyond the proposal of improving MDA through catalyst innovations, there are changes to the process that might shift the deactivation profile in useful ways or could help hold the deactivation profile within the desirable plateau regime of maximum selectivity and acceptable conversion. The lack of obvious progress with respect to catalyst composition suggests that the ‘engineering’ route may be the most direct path to a viable process. Our analysis demonstrates that deactivation profiles remain relatively unchanged with changes in residence time, H2O and CO cofeeds, reactor type, or CH4-H2 feed switching. The latter has emerged as the preferred method of keeping the catalyst within an acceptable performance level for longer [70–72], so it is useful to see that the fundamental catalyst structure is probably unchanged from that of steady-state operation. With respect to shifting the deactivation profile, apparently advantageous reaction conditions include pre-carburization / pre-reduction in diluted CH4 and/or H2, ammonization of the support, or the addition of an H2 scavenger. From a balance of plant perspective, however, caution must be exercised when comparing these approaches. For example, pre-carburization in CH4 still consumes CH4 in ways that do not produce aromatics. Not including this phase of reactor operation is, to some extent, a mathematical artifact that does not necessarily improve aromatic yields when the entire process is considered. Likewise, H2 pre-reduction consumes a valuable product, and ammonization and H2 scavengers would require re-addition each regeneration cycle. Regardless of the approach, these selectivity vs. conversion plots are a simple, data-driven way to compare the sizable MDA literature. The shapes of these plots are more complex than, for example, selective oxidation reactions that typically show a monotonic decline in selectivity with conversion [124,125], but they are highly diagnostic for MDA and readily allow one to compare and contrast approaches and to guide future research efforts. We believe they are much more useful than single-point descriptions of catalysts at their ‘best’ performance. Finally, we comment briefly on the process of developing these comparison plots. In MDA, plots of yield or conversion vs. TOS are the most common, partially for the obvious reason that this is how the data emerges from the reactor. Unfortunately, this format makes comparisons challenging due to the complex transient behavior of these materials, and plots of yields alone make process evaluation impossible. Well beyond MDA, tables of literature results (e.g. our Table 2) often include a single value that purports to capture conversion, selectivity, or yield, even though the conditions of the original studies may vary wildly. In some systems, this leads to clear pareto-optimal fronts in selectivity vs. conversion that can motivate future research, e.g. in the oxidative coupling of methane [126]. In many other cases, it can lead to data sets that seem to defy comparison or easy cataloging, or it can lead to inaccurate claims of creating a ‘better’ catalyst. Meta-analyses where primary data are re-analyzed and combined, such as we have done here, are standard practice in most clinical (medical) research [127]. They are increasingly viewed as a path to advance fields like catalysis that have not typically used them, and it is often argued that advances in natural language processing or machine learning algorithms now make this possible [128,129]. We close by noting that this study was carried out using only simple, long-existing data extraction tools without recourse to natural language processing of the primary literature or machine learning algorithms for the data analysis. Much can still be learned from historical data without advanced data science tools. coredata.dc:description: CH4 exists in great abundance and is used primarily as an energy source. Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) is a promising route for its direct transformation into liquid hydrocarbons and H2. Mo/H-ZSM-5 is the benchmark catalyst, but it deactivates rapidly by carbonaceous species formation. Here, we evaluated Mo/H-ZSM-5 formulations as a function of MoOx loading, SiO2/Al2O3 ratio, and Mo loading method for their impact on one-pass catalyst deactivation and after cycles of isothermal oxidative regeneration. The profiles of the rate of methane transformation to hydrocarbons vs. contact time show similar values for all catalysts with Mo/Al< 0.5. Similarly, the catalytic profiles of C6H6 selectivity vs. conversion overlap for all the formulations tested, indicating a non-selective deactivation pathway intrinsic to these Mo/H-ZSM-5 and giving the same active sites regardless of preparation method. Similar trends are observed after multiple rounds of isothermal oxidative regeneration. We then reanalyzed results from three decades of MDA studies. C6H6 selectivity vs. conversion profiles are very similar across most studies with Mo/H-ZSM-5 and related supports. While the rate at which catalysts might traverse the induction, activation, and deactivation phases may be highly dependent on materials properties, only a few pre-treatment or reaction conditions gave fundamentally different behavior. Finally, we broaden the scope to review and experimentally test other transition metals on ZSM-5, highlighting the anomalously-high C6H6 selectivities at low CH4 conversion for Zn and Mn under catalytic conditions similar to those of the benchmark Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst. This meta-review combined with experimental validation helps identify leads for further investigation with respect to reaction conditions and/or catalyst formulation.
